Generating posterior draws¶

Maud’s main purpose is to generate an ensemble of samples that collectively represent the information contained in some input data.

To generate samples for input data at path/to/myinput.toml, run the following command:

maud sample path/to/data --n_chains=3 --n_warmup=200 --n_samples=100

This will use the data file at path/to/myinput.toml to create a Stan program, compile it into a C++ Stan model, then start three independent MCMC chains, each using 200 iterations for adaptation and storing the contents of 100 further iterations in a csv file. All the files will be stored in the directory where the command is run unless the option output_dir is specified.

Here is the full documentation for the sample command, listing all available options:

sample¶

Sample from the model defined by the data at data_path.

sample [OPTIONS] [DATA_PATH]

Options

--rel_tol <rel_tol>¶

ODE solver’s relative tolerance parameter

--abs_tol <abs_tol>¶

ODE solver’s absolute tolerance parameter

--max_num_steps <max_num_steps>¶

ODE solver’s maximum steps parameter

--likelihood <likelihood>¶

Whether (1) or not (0) to run the model in likelihood mode

--n_samples <n_samples>¶

Number of post-warmup posterior samples

--n_warmup <n_warmup>¶

Number of warmup samples

--n_chains <n_chains>¶

Number of MCMC chains

--n_cores <n_cores>¶

Number of chains to run in parallel

--timepoint <timepoint>¶

How long the ODE simulates for (Units are whatever your time units are)

--output_dir <output_dir>¶

Where to save Maud’s output

--threads_per_chain <threads_per_chain>¶

How many threads per chain

--save_warmup <save_warmup>¶

Whether to save warmup draws

Arguments

DATA_PATH¶

Optional argument

Maud
